refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns TRUE if A's 2D bounding box intersects B's 2D bounding box.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The && operator returns TRUE if the 2D bounding box of geometry A intersects the 2D bounding box of geometry B.

note.para: This operand will make use of any indexes that may be available on the geometries.

refsection.para: Enhanced: 2.0.0 support for Polyhedral surfaces was introduced.
Availability: 1.5.0 support for geography was introduced.
&curve_support;
&P_support;

refsection.title: Examples
refsection.programlisting:
SELECT tbl1.column1, tbl2.column1, tbl1.column2 && tbl2.column2 AS overlaps FROM ( VALUES (1, 'LINESTRING(0 0, 3 3)'::geometry), (2, 'LINESTRING(0 1, 0 5)'::geometry)) AS tbl1, ( VALUES (3, 'LINESTRING(1 2, 4 6)'::geometry)) AS tbl2;
column1 | column1 | overlaps ---------+---------+---------- 1 | 3 | t 2 | 3 | f (2 rows)

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns TRUE if A's 3D bounding box intersects B's 3D bounding box.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The &&& operator returns TRUE if the n-D bounding box of geometry A intersects the n-D bounding box of geometry B.

note.para: This operand will make use of any indexes that may be available on the geometries.

refsection.para: Availability: 2.0.0
&curve_support;
&P_support;
&T_support;
&Z_support;

refsection.title: Examples: 3D LineStrings
refsection.programlisting:
SELECT tbl1.column1, tbl2.column1, tbl1.column2 &&& tbl2.column2 AS overlaps_3d, tbl1.column2 && tbl2.column2 AS overlaps_2d FROM ( VALUES (1, 'LINESTRING Z(0 0 1, 3 3 2)'::geometry), (2, 'LINESTRING Z(1 2 0, 0 5 -1)'::geometry)) AS tbl1, ( VALUES (3, 'LINESTRING Z(1 2 1, 4 6 1)'::geometry)) AS tbl2;
column1 | column1 | overlaps_3d | overlaps_2d ---------+---------+-------------+------------- 1 | 3 | t | t 2 | 3 | f | t

column1 | column1 | overlaps_3zm | overlaps_2d ---------+---------+-------------+------------- 1 | 3 | t | t 2 | 3 | f | t

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns TRUE if A's bounding box overlaps or is to the left of B's.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The &< operator returns TRUE if the bounding box of geometry A overlaps or is to the left of the bounding box of geometry B, or more accurately, overlaps or is NOT to the right of the bounding box of geometry B.

note.para: This operand will make use of any indexes that may be available on the geometries.

refsection.title: Examples
refsection.programlisting:
SELECT tbl1.column1, tbl2.column1, tbl1.column2 &< tbl2.column2 AS overleft FROM ( VALUES (1, 'LINESTRING(1 2, 4 6)'::geometry)) AS tbl1, ( VALUES (2, 'LINESTRING(0 0, 3 3)'::geometry), (3, 'LINESTRING(0 1, 0 5)'::geometry), (4, 'LINESTRING(6 0, 6 1)'::geometry)) AS tbl2;
column1 | column1 | overleft ---------+---------+---------- 1 | 2 | f 1 | 3 | f 1 | 4 | t (3 rows)

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The &<| operator returns TRUE if the bounding box of geometry A overlaps or is below of the bounding box of geometry B, or more accurately, overlaps or is NOT above the bounding box of geometry B.

column1 | column1 | overbelow ---------+---------+----------- 1 | 2 | f 1 | 3 | t 1 | 4 | t (3 rows)

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns TRUE if A's bounding box is the same as B's. Uses double precision bounding box.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The = operator returns TRUE if the bounding box of geometry/geography A is the same as the bounding box of geometry/geography B. PostgreSQL uses the =, <, and > operators defined for geometries to perform internal orderings and comparison of geometries (ie. in a GROUP BY or ORDER BY clause).

warning.para: This is cause for a lot of confusion. When you compare geometryA = geometryB it will return true even when the geometries are clearly different IF their bounding boxes are the same. To check for true equality use or

caution.para: This operand will NOT make use of any indexes that may be available on the geometries.

refsection.para: &curve_support;
&P_support;

Changed: 2.0.0 , the bounding box of geometries was changed to use double precision instead of float4 precision of prior. The side effect of this is that in particular points in prior versions that were a little different may have returned true in prior versions and false in 2.0+ since their float4 boxes would be the same but there float8 (double precision), would be different.

refsection.title: Examples
refsection.programlisting:
SELECT 'LINESTRING(0 0, 0 1, 1 0)'::geometry = 'LINESTRING(1 1, 0 0)'::geometry; ?column? ---------- t (1 row)
SELECT ST_AsText(column1) FROM ( VALUES ('LINESTRING(0 0, 1 1)'::geometry), ('LINESTRING(1 1, 0 0)'::geometry)) AS foo; st_astext --------------------- LINESTRING(0 0,1 1) LINESTRING(1 1,0 0) (2 rows)
-- Note: the GROUP BY uses the "=" to compare for geometry equivalency. SELECT ST_AsText(column1) FROM ( VALUES ('LINESTRING(0 0, 1 1)'::geometry), ('LINESTRING(1 1, 0 0)'::geometry)) AS foo GROUP BY column1; st_astext --------------------- LINESTRING(0 0,1 1) (1 row)
-- In versions prior to 2.0, this used to return true -- SELECT ST_GeomFromText('POINT(1707296.37 4820536.77)') = ST_GeomFromText('POINT(1707296.27 4820536.87)') As pt_intersect;
--pt_intersect -- f

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns TRUE if A's bounding box is strictly to the right of B's.

refsection.title: Description

refsection.title: Examples
refsection.programlisting:
SELECT tbl1.column1, tbl2.column1, tbl1.column2 >> tbl2.column2 AS right FROM ( VALUES (1, 'LINESTRING (2 3, 5 6)'::geometry)) AS tbl1, ( VALUES (2, 'LINESTRING (1 4, 1 7)'::geometry), (3, 'LINESTRING (6 1, 6 5)'::geometry), (4, 'LINESTRING (0 0, 4 3)'::geometry)) AS tbl2;
column1 | column1 | right ---------+---------+------- 1 | 2 | t 1 | 3 | f 1 | 4 | f (3 rows)

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns TRUE if A's bounding box is contained by B's.

column1 | column1 | contained ---------+---------+----------- 1 | 2 | t 1 | 3 | f 1 | 4 | t (3 rows)

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns TRUE if A's bounding box contains B's.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns TRUE if A's bounding box is the same as B's.

refsection.title: Description

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the distance between two points. For point / point checks it uses floating point accuracy (as opposed to the double precision accuracy of the underlying point geometry). For other geometry types the distance between the floating point bounding box centroids is returned. Useful for doing distance ordering and nearest neighbor limits using KNN gist functionality.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The <-> operator returns distance between two points read from the spatial index for points (float precision). For other geometries it returns the distance from centroid of bounding box of geometries. Useful for doing nearest neighbor approximate distance ordering.

note.para: This operand will make use of any indexes that may be available on the geometries. It is different from other operators that use spatial indexes in that the spatial index is only used when the operator is in the ORDER BY clause.
Index only kicks in if one of the geometries is a constant (not in a subquery/cte). e.g. 'SRID=3005;POINT(1011102 450541)'::geometry instead of a.geom

refsection.para: Availability: 2.0.0 only available for PostgreSQL 9.1+

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the distance between bounding box of 2 geometries. For point / point checks it's almost the same as distance (though may be different since the bounding box is at floating point accuracy and geometries are double precision). Useful for doing distance ordering and nearest neighbor limits using KNN gist functionality.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The <#> KNN GIST operator returns distance between two floating point bounding boxes read from the spatial index if available. Useful for doing nearest neighbor approximate distance ordering.

note.para: This operand will make use of any indexes that may be available on the geometries. It is different from other operators that use spatial indexes in that the spatial index is only used when the operator is in the ORDER BY clause.
Index only kicks in if one of the geometries is a constant e.g. ORDER BY (ST_GeomFromText('POINT(1 2)') <#> geom) instead of g1.geom <#>.

refsection.para: Availability: 2.0.0 only available for PostgreSQL 9.1+
